data.title: Alibaba Set To Report Earnings While Investors Watch Out For Jobs Data
data.description:
Get ahead of the market by subscribing to Seeking Alpha's Wall Street Week Ahead, a preview of key events scheduled for the coming week. The newsletter keeps you informed of the biggest stories set to make headlines, including upcoming IPOs, investor days, earnings reports, and conference presentations.

Wall Street's major market averages traded lower on Friday as the January wholesale inflation report came in hotter than expected. On the economic front, the January U.S. Producer Price Index came in at +0.5% M/M versus the +0.3% consensus and +0.5% prior figure. Also, core PPI (excluding food and energy) came in at +0.8% M/M compared to the +0.3% consensus and +0.7% prior readings.

As the earnings season eases, investors will look out for major economic indicators in the coming week. The S&P Global Manufacturing PMI and ISM Manufacturing PMI for February are due on Monday, with the non-manufacturing PMI set to be released later in the week on Wednesday. On Thursday, initial jobless claims data will be released, with retail sales data and nonfarm payrolls scheduled for Friday.

Alibaba (BABA), CrowdStrike (CRWD), and Broadcom (AVGO) are among the companies reporting their results next week.

_______________________________________________________________

Earnings spotlight: Monday: Riot Platform (RIOT), Core Scientific (CORZ), Plug Power (PLUG). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Tuesday: CrowdStrike, Ross Stores (ROST). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Wednesday: Broadcom, Okta (OKTA). See the full earnings calendar.

Earnings spotlight: Thursday: Costco (COST), Alibaba. See the full earnings calendar.

Volatility watch: AST SpaceMobile (ASTS) and Xenon Pharmaceuticals (XENE) are set up for a volatile week of trading based on options volume. The most overbought stocks per their 14-day relative strength index include ATI Inc. (ATI), Keysight (KEYS), and Nordic American Tankers (NAT). The most oversold stocks per their 14-day Relative Strength Index include Gossamer Bio (GOSS), FuboTV (FUBO), and Oddity Tech (ODD). Short interest is elevated on software stocks UiPath (PATH), Duolingo (DUOL), CoreWeave (CRWV), and RingCentral (RNG).

IPO watch: MiniMed Group (MMED) will start trading after being separated from Medtronic (MDT), which will still own about 90% of the company. The analyst quiet period expires on Forgent Power Solutions (FPS), Eikon Therapeutics (EIKN), Bob's Discount Furniture (BOBS), and Veradermics (MANE) to free up analysts to post ratings.

Dividend watch: Companies that have an ex-dividend date coming next week include Allstate (ALL), Lam Research (LRCX), Cigna (CI), and Qualcomm (QCOM).

Alibaba Earnings Preview: Alibaba is set to report third-quarter earnings of $1.58 on revenue of $42.18B. The third quarter print is seen as pivotal for the firm's earnings recovery. Analysts expect the firm to show some improvement after mixed second-quarter earnings. Alibaba's investments in cloud infrastructure, AI capacity expansion, and rapid commerce are strengthening its positioning for long-term structural growth and enhanced ecosystem monetization. However, it continues to face challenges due to fierce competition and uncertainties in its core market in China. Heavy investments in Quick Commerce could continue to impact EBITA and margin stability.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: NFTY: Comparatively Better, Structurally Weak
data.description:
Analysis

The First Trust India Nifty 50 Equal Weight ETF (NFTY) executes an equal-weight portfolio strategy across the constituent stocks of the Nifty 50, the flagship Indian stock market index. India has been on a structural growth trajectory—and that continues to be the case, supported by a favorable economic outlook and a young population base, with roughly 65% of people being under the age of 35.

The Indian economic growth outlook from the recent EY report reflects this strong trajectory. The report suggests the GDP to reach around $26 trillion before 2050, with per capita income exceeding $15,000—a significant milestone considering the largeness of the population and the current number. Even though these are projected estimates, they are capable of drawing the point about India’s forward looking growth prospects.

While India has been on a structural growth trajectory—and that continues to be the case—the translation of that growth into investor returns might need closer examination. The point, as an equity investor, is how much of that growth can actually be translated into stock market returns, which are a function of current valuations and forward expectations.

Long-term returns are a function of earnings growth, dividends, and changes in the P/E multiple. Betting on P/E expansion only makes sense from a relatively low starting base, which is not exactly the case here.

In a nutshell, while the Indian growth story may remain intact, how much of that ultimately translates into stock market appreciation needs to be examined. This becomes even more relevant for investors domiciled outside India, who must account for currency differentials, along with other associated factors. An investment that may appear attractive for an India-based investor could become materially less attractive for someone based in the US once currency dynamics are factored in.

The exposure to India via ETFs

For investors based outside India who seek exposure to Indian equities, ETFs provide a relatively simple and convenient vehicle for participation.

However, when the performance of these ETFs is compared either with the underlying benchmark indices they track or just with S&P 500, the picture looks materially different.

NFTY generated cumulatively 132.02% over the last 10 years vs 247% for S&P 500. While INDY, which also invests in India, but tracks Nifty50, has cumulatively returned 126%.

Case for divergence — It would be important to see what had been the cause of material underperformance of ETFs tracking Indian indices. Firstly, if we look into the local benchmark returns that these ETFs track, they have performed fairly well.

The 5-year returns of Nifty 50 had been around 14% CAGR while for Nifty50 Equal weight Index— it had been even better—around 19%.

iShares India 50 ETF INDY and First Trust India Nifty 50 Equal Weight ETF NFTY, over the same period, have cumulatively returned approximately 31% and 55%, respectively. On an annualized basis, this translates to a ~5.56% CAGR for INDY and ~9.21% CAGR for NFTY.

Now observe this: the difference in returns between the Nifty 50 Equal Weight Index and the Nifty 50 has been roughly around 4% annually. Similarly, the return spread between NFTY and INDY has also been in the vicinity of nearly 4% annually. So, the relative differential remains broadly intact. However, the overall returns of both ETFs are materially lower than their respective domestic benchmarks.

Nifty 50 – 5-Year CAGR: 14%

iShares India 50 ETF (INDY) – 5-Year CAGR: 5.56%

Nifty 50 Equal Weight Index – 5-Year CAGR: 19%

First Trust India Nifty 50 Equal Weight ETF (NFTY) – 5-Year CAGR: ~9.21%

Roughly both the ETFs have underperformed their local benchmarks by around 10%. A little rounding of difference is on account of tracking errors, expense ratios, and some other factors. But the point remains intact.

The resultant divergence is attributable to INR depreciation against the USD over the same period, which materially reduced USD-denominated returns despite strong underlying local index performance.

The INR (Indian Rupee) had approximately depreciated by around 24% for the same 5-year period against the US dollar, which resulted in significant return differential between the benchmark local returns and US-denominated returns.

Currency— USD vs INRs

Over the last 20 years, the USD has appreciated roughly 100% against the INR. This approximates to approximately 3.5% annualized depreciation of the INR. This is not insignificant. If we compare more recent periods, the magnitude of depreciation has been quite higher. Therefore, unless we witness a meaningful structural shift in the relative economic dynamics of India and the United States, the prevailing pattern seems likely to persist for the time being.

Provisional Summary

To sum it up, what this suggests is that although the underlying benchmarks and the local economy may appear compelling, when analyzed in terms of take-home returns, the recent outcomes have not even exceeded those of the S&P 500.

Comparative Analysis

Nifty50 Equal weight vs Nifty 50

Over a 20-year period, the Equal Weight Index has delivered an additional 1.8% CAGR relative to the Nifty 50. The data is as of January 2021, but that does not dilute the inference—two decades is sufficiently long to capture multiple market cycles. We do not want to draw conclusions from cyclical comparisons but rather from how something has fared across cycles. That is not insignificant alpha.

Further, across 22 calendar years, the equal-weighted portfolio outperformed the market-capitalization index in 13 years.

Kindly note: Nifty 50 Equal Weight refers to an index constructed from the constituents of the Nifty 50, with each stock assigned an equal weight of approximately 2%. In contrast, the Nifty 50 is a broad free-float market capitalization–weighted index, where constituent weights are determined in accordance with the index methodology.

NFTY – Equal-Weighted Nifty 50 Strategy vs. iShares India ETF – Free-Float Market-Cap Weighted Strategy

The structural advantage of an equal-weighted strategy lies in its inherent design, which functions as a mechanical rebalancing tool. By mandate, the portfolio must periodically trim outperformers and buy underperformers to maintain equal weights, effectively forcing a "buy low, sell high" discipline. Yes, it is cutting down the flowers and watering the weeds, and that works in this context.

While this approach is not a viable framework for active stock picking—since it ignores a company’s fundamental developments. However, it presents an interesting case for ETFs and index fund universe. Essentially, the strategy favours companies that are currently underperforming in terms of quotational price basis by increasing their stake while selling off those that have surged. It consists of an element of mean reversion— that causes a slight better performance than the broad-based capitalization weighted indexes.

In that sense, NFTY has certain advantages over other broad-based capitalization weighted index traded funds such as INDY and similar others.

Risk & Other Factors

The most important constraint in any equal weight index is capacity—that is, the capital it can deploy under its mandate. As opposed to capitalization-focused indices, which naturally constitute weights by taking into account their tradable free float, an equal weight strategy necessarily allocates the same amount of capital irrespective of the size, volume, and liquidity of the underlying company. Thus, for any equal weighted mandate, as the fund size grows, this structure can mechanically increase market impact, execution friction, and tracking error, thereby reducing scalability and attractiveness. That makes it comparatively less efficient for sizable allocations relative to market capitalization indices.

In addition, as already mentioned, currency depreciation can meaningfully reduce returns for a US-domiciled investor even when the underlying entities are performing fairly well. Total return for such an investor is a function of both local equity performance and currency movement. The return attributable to a domestic investor would, in a depreciation cycle, exceed that of a USD-based investor. Currency hedging may be an option for some investors; however, hedges are neither costless nor particularly convenient to manage.

Takeaway

While I believe the Indian economic outlook and growth trajectory to be in line with the expectations, I do not feel convinced about the attractiveness of broader stock market indices from the lenses of foreign investors. Neither I buy the narrative of the Indian growth story with reference to broad-based stock market optimism, and even if one does, once currency volatility and fluctuations are accounted for, the case becomes materially weaker for an investor domiciled outside India, such as in the United States.

Nevertheless, for someone who intends to maintain exposure to the broader Indian equity market regardless, NFTY offers an interesting avenue, providing an equal-weighted exposure to the largest enterprises in India.

I consider exposure via NFTY to be comparatively better than that of iShares India 50 ETF (INDY) or other ETFs tracking the Nifty 50, unless the allocation size is a constraint. The Nifty 50 Equal Weight Index has a reasonable probability of continuing to outperform the traditional Nifty 50, and ETFs based on the equal-weight methodology may continue to reflect that advantage over some more time.

data.title: GCM Grosvenor: Low Carry Could Signal Latent Growth On PE Thaw
data.description:
We covered GCM Grosvenor (GCMG) previously on the basis of a private markets thawing thesis. The concept simply was that with a few rate cuts in, and making their way through the digestive system of markets, the long-lost private market sponsor component would be reanimated in capital markets. It was beginning to prove out among the advisory shops and the data in general as discussed previously that deals with financial sponsors were resuming. For Grosvenor this still hasn't really kicked in, and given that it's lagging the rest of the markets we continue the recovery in carried interest in the mix to be a latent effect that will help 2026 figures at some point. Until then fundraising at record levels, driven by their successful, idiosyncratic cross-selling strategy has been driving figures. In terms of the recent market wobbles around SaaS, we also note that Grosvenor has not been meaningfully exposed and may even benefit in their ARS (effectively alternative public markets or hedge fund offerings) businesses in the form of higher performance fees (carried interest being the performance fees but for the private businesses which are all ex-ARS). It's still appears cheap on an EV/AUM basis compared to other PE GP peers.

Results

Commenting on some of the business elements as they reflect the markets, we note lagging PE AUM growth. This is consistent with private credit taking up more share and picking up the slack to keep the private category growing. Absolute return strategies or ARS have been flat over the last few years, but up recently. Hedge funds and other alternative, more public markets related AM has been sidelined for a decade now in favour of the massively growing private equity industry, which has been fundraising successfully and building dry powder even in these last couple of years when portfolio turnover has been really low. Hence private markets AUM has grown considerably as a percentage of the business over the last few years.

In terms of more immediate results. Fundraising has been at record levels across geographies and asset classes in Q4. The expectation is flat growth into Q1 2026, so sequentially into the next quarter, as it concerns private markets but up 5% as it concerns ARS on great performance and fundraising. ARS could get an extra benefit from SaaS volatility in the Q1, up until that point only 4% of overall AUM and less than 6% of credit AUM is exposed to SaaS across their assets, and hedge funds should be able to pick up some babies thrown out with the bathwater for Q1 performance, as there has been a selective recovery in SaaS stocks that aren't actually that exposed to AI or may even be the tool of agentic AI down the line.

Carried interest is up, though "old" carry is down as reported by management, but there is still more accrual on NAV calculations than actual realisations of carry on exits. Hence overall unrealised carry is up and that does reflect a situation where there is still limited liquidity in private markets due to reticent sponsor activity.

This is borne out also in the fee breakdown. Performance fees coming from ARS are up YoY while carried interest in down. Seasonally, Q4 isn't usually the strongest quarter with Q3 taking that spot, but carried interest is really low here. We think the building unrealised interest does signal a considerable latent component as it's likely that realisations will start accelerating with costs of capital normalising, perhaps headed even lower once Powell is out and Warsh is in - although no assurances of that.

In general, we expect latent growth with 12% AUM growth but not yet fee paying AUM growth up 27% per year. In general, the cross selling strategy continues to be a major lever for the business' top line with 20-25% of fundraising in any given year having come from cross selling products to existing clients. Considerable operating leverage has been achieved and the company believes it can keep that OpEx at controlled levels. We've actually seen this before with more idiosyncratic AM platforms.

There is also additional growth coming in from new initiatives to tap wealth management distribution by offering white label solutions and other semi-liquid funds that can work in a wealth management distribution model and move more retail money at wealth managers into underallocated alternative assets. Wealth management is only 5% of Grosvenor capital currently and could be a lot more given that retail wealth is secularly underallocated to alternative assets.

Bottom Line

Grosvenor traded down together with the markets and they tactically increased their buyback by $35 million, meaning $91 million left in the programme. They also refinanced for $3 million in interest savings, which is alone a couple of pct points of net income in 2025. The dividend yield is not that low on Grosvenor either, and the buyback will reduce the cash burden from paying dividends to those extra shares. It's a constructive capital allocation strategy. In terms of valuation, the EV/AUM is around 2.6%. Partners Group has around a 15% as a PE and alternative assets comp based on their latest AUM disclosure. It comes across as still cheap. We feel they should be able to monetise their AUM nearly as well as Partners Group in a low cost of capital environment.

data.title: Climb: A Structural Transformation Still Trading Like A Traditional Distributor
data.description:
Investment Summary

Climb Global Solutions Inc. (CLMB) is an American IT distributor focusing on emerging technologies, such as AI or cybersecurity. It operates mostly in the US but recently expanded to Europe.

The business pivoted in 2020 when leadership changed; Dale Foster and Charles Bass (ex-Promark, acquired by Ingram Micro Holding (INGM), one of Climb's main competitors) turned around the business and rebranded it (from Wayside Technology Group to Climb Global Solutions).

Under their strategy, Climb started focusing on high-value, high-touch distribution of high-tech software, moving away from a low value-add model that is less differentiated from the large, traditional IT distributors in North America.

EPS went from $2.73 in 2023 to $4.64 in 2025, evidence that profitability is expanding. Climb is a cash generator with a strong net cash position ($36.6M in Q4/25). Share count has been stable, broadly speaking, and insider ownership is high, so interests are aligned.

We see fair value for late 2026 at around $140 per share (from today's $90, a 55% valuation gap) as our central case, with a downside/base case at $120 (33% gap) and a bullish case increasing the target up to $160 (78% gap).

Business Description

Climb is an intermediary between tech vendors and a network of over 7000 clients, who are mostly resellers consultants but also integrators or end customers.

It is operating a capital-light business, which selectively accepts to distribute the most innovative software to add to its current stack, and then distribute them through its growing network and partnerships.

Climb Channel Solutions is Climb's largest and fastest-growing segment. This is the main division that distributes the vendors' software, i.e. cloud, cybersecurity, AI.

Grey Matter is the cloud architecture division focused on migration and integration. It comes as a complementary service to Channel Solutions to help integrate the vendors' solutions in the end-customers IT environment. This is a more niche but high-margin business.

Historically, Climb was distributing almost 500 vendors' technology, but was lacking a proper sales force and so was much more passive in its distribution. They had no vendor onboarding process, which was creating bottlenecks. Both factors made it harder to sign qualified vendors.

Larger, famous, easy-to-sell software (Salesforce (CRM), for instance) was going to the larger competitors (TD Synnex (SNX), Arrow Electronics (ARW), Ingram) as the latter had way more scale and brand visibility. Scalability was poor, and the offer had no real differentiation.

Following the pivot operated by Dale (cf. Investment Summary), CLMB is now targeting those niche software that are differentiated from the current market offerings, because the extent to which Climb gets paid depends on the adoption as they run on a fee-per-subscription model, which is why they want to focus on innovative products.

A strong element of the business model is that adding more selective products to the distribution stacks increases the capacity of Climb to cross-sell various products to the same clients, which is one of the drivers behind the company's potential operating leverage.

Investment Thesis

a) Core Mispricing

Climb is not only improving through volume expansion (gross billings up 18%) but also in terms of net sales (+40% in 2025). The divergence between the two metrics does not necessarily imply higher take rates, but shows they have a more central role in vendors' transactions (acting more often as a principal than an agent this year vs. last year).

Typically, a principal transaction recognizes gross revenue in US GAAP accounting, and an agent transaction is reported as net revenue. This can inflate net sales relative to gross profit, which is why we think the best metrics to look at to understand the dynamic of the business on a quarterly and yearly basis are gross profits and EBITDA.

In 2025, gross profit grew 15.5% against 2024 (close to gross billings), which shows improving economics despite the change in revenue mix.

This is confirmed by management saying if you remove the Q4/24 one-off, higher margin transaction they had, organic growth in terms of EBITDA would have been in the high teens in Q4/25, the market basically thinks that Climb is still stuck in its traditional distribution model, capturing a small share of gross billings, having low growth, with lumpy revenues quarter to quarter.

b) Strategic Positioning

Climb's new positioning is that of a high-value-added model that is agile and unique, as they bring deep technical expertise to these more niche products they distribute and put a lot of commercial effort (webinars, marketing campaigns) into helping them gain traction, contrary to the more passive approach of the traditional players. For Climb, this active support enables them to capture more revenue per transaction for better profitability over time.

Clients are satisfied because they are being pitched new, highly-selected solutions that they might not have been exposed to otherwise. Vendors selling emerging technologies are satisfied because they are often structurally underserved by the larger distributors that prefer to sell already proven, easy-to-sell, commoditized products and get visibility from Climb's huge network, a real boost for them in terms of commercial traction.

c) Quality of revenue and economics improving

IT Distribution remains a cyclical business with a disproportionate share of the revenues being back-end loaded each year. That said, as CLMB matures, management indicated that it is becoming less lumpy (no "lumpy deals" in Q4/25), and concentration is being actively reduced as growth was generated across a large set of vendors, not just CLMB's top ones.

Over the past few years, the average order size increased from roughly $200 to around $1500, according to management, showing a shift in scale. On top of that, they spoke about an 80 to 90% client renewal rate in Q4/25, indicating very low churn, with management targeting over 100% of renewal rate in the coming quarters. This gives a lot of visibility and improves the durability of gross profits.

Beyond revenue stability, management wants to improve the operational efficiency of the business. The CEO mentioned in Q4/25 earnings 'call that they still perform roughly 12 quotes per order processed (meaning their internal workflow is still too manual). Management recognised this problem and hired a CIO whose mission, in part, is to introduce AI to streamline such processes. In the coming years, they expect output to increase "by 50%" with the exact "same workforce". The new ERP they just implemented is another meaningful step in that direction, as it helps standardize workflows and facilitate automation.

This would be material for operating leverage and for the thesis, as a) our base case valuation model relies on improving EBITDA margins, but b) the bull case (more in valuation below) actually relies on the appearance of operating leverage, which will come from either higher gross profit per dollar of gross billings and/or faster gross profit growth than SG&A growth through ERP/AI efficiency.

d) Vertical Exposure

As mentioned above, Climb's moat relies on its deep vertical expertise within key high growth markets. One such market is cybersecurity, which represents over 60% of Climb's sales. They mentioned they "do not see weakness there".

Another key segment for Climb is AI, where many emerging software vendors are positioning to capture the AI data center investment cycle. Climb believes it has a $20B Total Addressable Market there, before it "reaches a ceiling". They therefore believe they have a lot of room to grow from its roughly $2.1B of total billings this year.

Climb is also present in the Data Migration and Storage software markets.

e) Vendor Improvement

Climb recently signed two very significant vendors, which should provide significant runway in the coming years: Fortinet (large US cybersecurity company, a 60B+ market cap) and Darktrace (large UK cybersecurity company).

Fortinet was signed in late 2025 through direct C-Level access, which shows that Climb is already being visible and recognized among the largest tech vendors. Climb is targeting in gross billings 10% of Fortinet's $2.5B TAM in the US, or potentially $250M within the next 18 months, which would be very meaningful against what Climb billed in 2025. Management expects Fortinet to soon become its top 3 vendor in the US.

Darktrace, also in the early stage of market penetration, was already contributing to $13M in gross billings in Q4/25, suggesting a $50M annual run-rate already, with possible upside coming into 2026.

These contracts should be very good drivers of billings growth, but such large clients tend to provide very good volume rebates to their partners if distribution is successful, which would be very impactful towards margins in case of success.

The pipeline of new vendors keeps getting bigger, as management indicated in the last earnings call that there is a "huge pipeline" of vendors doing $100M ARR in Europe and North America. Climb's very selective approach to vendors (in Q4/25, management said they assessed around 100 potential partnerships with vendors, only signing the top two promising ones) ensures they only distribute software platforms with high product-market-fit and adoption, which should continue boosting Climb moving forward.

As Climb naturally increases the number of products it distributes, it increases the cross-selling opportunities across its extended network, creating an extra compounding effect on growth. Grey Matter, the integration business of Climb, is also expected to benefit from a larger software portfolio.

f) M&A Flywheel

Climb is choosing to also grow inorganically through acquisitions. The DDS acquisition it did in 2024 was transformative. It was fully funded in cash and contributed to revenue and helped increase EPS immediately.

This acquisition allowed Climb to gain a strong foothold in Europe, a fragmented market where there are many sub-$200M distributors but few significant competitors. A new acquisition was just announced a couple weeks ago with Interworks, a cloud distributor based in Greece. Climb bought them at around 9x Adjusted-EBITDA (8M euro acquisition price for 0.9M euro Adj-EBITDA), for a business that was growing its EBITDA 86% YoY.

Beyond the contribution to the top and bottom line, this move allows Climb to strengthen its bond with the Microsoft CSP ecosystem, and adds over 600 additional resellers and MSPs across South-Eastern Europe.

Climb's land-and-expand strategy is again immediately accretive without putting the company in much financial (the acquisition is paid for through cashflow, much less than the current cash position) or operational risk (Climb has been working with their team for over 10 years).

We can expect this acquisition streak to continue as cash is rebuilding rapidly with the strong FCF that CLMB generates. One to two new acquisitions are expected in 2026, as per management, not counting Interworks' acquisition in February 2026, with a special focus on Europe, which, according to management, looks like the US space between 2006 and 2017, when massive consolidation happened. This implies that market share should be taken in Europe, now.

With a clean balance sheet, a successful track record of acquisitions, and the stoppage of dividend payments from 2026 onward, we believe this angle strengthens the capital allocation story.

Financial Analysis

Q4/25 saw the highest ever revenue in a quarter printed for CLMB at $193.8M net sales; YoY net sales went up a meaningful 20%. That said, Q4/24 had a significant one-off high-margin vendor transaction explaining why EPS remained flat YoY for the quarter at GAAP $1.52.

For the quarter, gross margins as a percentage of net sales remained constant YoY at roughly 16%. As a percentage of gross billings, they went to just over 5%, when they were typically just below 5%. SG&A remained flat at roughly 3% to 3.5% of gross billings over the years and across cycles.

Regarding full-year 2025 results:

Net sales went up 40% to $653.3M and gross billings increased 18% to $2.1B. Gross profit grew 15.5%, less than gross billings (18%) and much less than net sales (40%), showing that revenue mix has changed, economics are stable but operating leverage is still ahead.

That said, SG&A should reduce as a percentage of revenue if Climb reinforces the economies of scale, improves synergies between the different business units, clears all redundancies between corporate entities following acquisitions, and implements more AI in its process (discussed above).

Further down the Income Statement, GAAP Net income went up 15% ($21.3M) leading to a $4.64 GAAP EPS in 2025 (against a $2.73 EPS in 2023 and a $4.06 EPS in 2024).

Historically, Climb turns close to 90% of its EBITDA into Free Cash Flow, a very strong conversion, proving strong working capital dynamics because their customers pay reliably and vendors pay fast. This explains the strong liquidity of the balance sheet, which had $36.6M in cash and equivalents in Q4/25 and $0.2M in outstanding debt, and a $50M untapped credit facility. Plenty of liquidity as a buffer and as a means to pursue their M&A strategy.

Valuation

Revenue compounded significantly in the last couple of years, a strong sign that this business is behaving differently from its peers, and should warrant a different valuation multiple.

Climb trades at a similar EV/EBITDA (9.3x) to TD Synnex or Arrow, even though it has a much higher YoY net sales and EBITDA growth than them.

Company* EV/SALES (TTM) EV/EBITDA (TTM) EBITDA Growth YoY (TTM) Revenue Growth (TTM YoY) P/E (TTM)
Climb Global Solutions 0.6x 9.3x 38.5% 51.1% 20.1x
TD Synnex Corporation 0.25x 8.4x 10.15% 6.94% 15.9x
Arrow Electronics 0.36x 10.4x -5.63% 10.49% 14.1x
Crayon Group Holding 2.05x 16.9x 21.24% 7.65% 46.7x
SoftwareOne Holding AG 0.78x 14.6x -44.18% -5.93% N/A
Average 0.8x 11.9x 4.01% 14.05% 24.2x
Median 0.6x 10.4x 10.15% 7.65% 18x**

*The data in this table was extracted from the Growth and Valuation tabs on Seeking Alpha on 27/2/2026, for each of the companies in the peer table.

**The median was the average of the third and fourth value, SoftwareOne Holding AG being unprofitable.

A reasonable EV/EBITDA multiple should be set depending on the growth of the EBITDA in 2026 (adjusted-EBITDA in the context of Climb). If our base case materializes (EBITDA margin remains constant and gross billings grows just as much as 2025, i.e. roughly 15% annually), then we could expect, on our assumptions, somewhere close to 48M adj-EBITDA in 2026. Applying the median 10.4x EV/EBITDA multiple would then give us roughly $500M of EV. Assuming $50M in net cash by year-end (given CLMB's current $36.6M cash position as of year-end 2025 with some FCF generation in 2026), this would give us roughly $550M of equity value or roughly $120 per share (a total of 4.6M shares) by the end of 2026.

A more bullish scenario (the one implying the appearance of operating leverage) could warrant a higher multiple. On roughly 50M adj-EBITDA (higher adj-EBITDA growth) in 2026 this time, applying a 14x multiple could imply a valuation closer to $160.

A mix of both scenarios would yield a fair value somewhere close to the $140 mark, which is our central case (over 50% above the current price). This target does not require heroic assumptions; it relies on Fortinet's integration succeeding with possibly another small, accretive M&A this year (management's track record suggests it should continue and is made possible by their significant cash position), slightly improving margins, and stable organic traction.

Besides, Climb is still largely under-followed compared to peers (only has two analysts following the stock), but we expect that the thesis will gather more attention as the structural transformation the business is undergoing becomes clearer. This should eventually help close the valuation gap.

Risks

Some risks remain for Climb, despite its recent successes.First, software distribution remains a fairly lumpy business, because even if the trend has been upward YoY for Climb, some quarters remain comparatively weaker to other ones, sometimes expectedly so (Q4 typically being stronger as explained before), sometimes being less reliably predictable as one significant, one-short high-margin billings may fall a given quarter and distort the QoQ or even YoY comparison, possibly creating bad optics for those investors preferring visibility over volatility of earnings.

Secondly, there remains a vendor concentration risks in the sense that a few vendors are representing a large proportion of revenues. This is a double-edged sword, as it also indicates that a successful partnership with a vendor can lead to very positive outcomes. Ultimately, vendor concentration is trending down as Climb structurally signs new emerging vendors and enlarge the technology stack it distributes.

Another risk could be an AI and/or Cybersecurity slowdown, as Cybersecurity is a major contributor to revenue, and AI is expected to represent a large TAM for the company in the coming years (with the rise of software orchestrating AI in data centers, for instance). That said, this can be said of any industry, and we believe these industries have a strong case for having real long-term tailwinds and significant traction in the coming years. Climb's diversification within these markets is also a way to remain "on the edge" of technological innovation at all times, which gives it downside protection if a particular sector within AI or cybersecurity were to slow down for a period of time.

Another risk is the possibility that competitors react aggressively to Climb's new strategy, of expanding to Europe, but above all to address the AI segment aggressively, which appears to be the market segment where there is the most room for growth (the $20B TAM ceiling described by management). This risk was actually discussed by management during the earnings call, but they do expect that so far they are flying "under the radar" to matter for its competitors, and so far they are addressing a different kind of market.

There remains the risk of a failed acquisition. In the past, M&A has been very accretive for CLMB, but this could stop the stock in its tracks in the event of a failed acquisition.

Last but not least, net sales and gross billings can be volatile from quarter to quarter depending on the revenue mix. The main drivers of the thesis will be QoQ/YoY gross profit and EBITDA growth, meaning the cost efficiency gains and the higher gross profit per dollar of billing will have to materialize for the bull case to materialize. Otherwise the base case (EBITDA growth through volume growth) will remain dominant for 2026.

Conclusion

CLMB has operated a successful structural transformation that improved its growth and gave the business a moat, which will be harder to replicate as CLMB becomes the go-to distribution specialist for emerging technologies in the coming years.

The verticals it serves (AI, Cloud, Cybersecurity) have strong tailwinds, which CLMB can benefit from, all while benefiting from the diversification working with so many vendors brings.

The business is scaling fast, yet costs have been kept under control while the balance remains clean, all signs that the business is operating a capital-light model. This enables CLMB to generate significant cash to further boost its growth through self-funded M&A.

All in all, this creates a gap between the business valuation and the estimated fair value across all metrics (P/E, EV/EBITDA) against peers, especially when taking growth into account.

The asymmetry appears favorable, especially if they maintain organic growth and continue their streak of accretive, non-dilutive acquisitions in less competitive markets.

We believe fair value as a central case lies at $140 per share by the end of 2026, meaningfully higher than the stock currently trades at.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Fickle Sentiment, High Yields: Why We Are Buying The BDC Panic
data.description:
Co-authored with Beyond Saving

Investor sentiment is fickle. There will be a news story that everyone is talking about as something so important to the markets. Then, a few months later, it just disappears.

Does anyone remember First Brands? We haven't seen anybody talk about it for months, but back in October 2025, First Brands was the excuse for the market to sell-off for credit risk investments. In particular, "private credit" was blamed, and investments like BDCs, private equity, and alternative asset managers sold off significantly. Nevermind that the debt was mostly owned and originated by banks, and private credit had little to do with it – that storyline has disappeared.

Now the market has focused on a new fear: AI and software. The current theory is that software companies aren't going to pay their loans because AI is going to disrupt their business.

Certainly, AI is going to "disrupt" many businesses in a similar manner that the Internet disrupted many businesses. That's technological innovation, and companies will adapt their business models.

No doubt some businesses might struggle with innovating and finding their path to provide value in a new world. That's life. Those who are lending first-lien senior secured loans to them, generally aren't the ones who end up feeling that risk.

When the market is fearful, it's time to go shopping for opportunities. Let's take a look at a few opportunities the market is giving us.

Pick #1: ARCC – Yield 10%

Ares Capital Corporation (ARCC) is one of our favorite buy-and-hold "forever" stocks. It is a premium BDC that focuses on the upper-middle market. It is an investment that frequently trades at a premium to NAV, but has recently started trading at a discount to its last reported NAV of $19.94.

What has changed? Well, nothing. ARCC is doing the same thing it has always done. Credit quality remains consistent with non-accruals at 1.8% of amortized cost and 1.2% of fair value: Source

ARCC's leverage remains low relative to their historical averages, and well within management's target range:

ARCC is doing the same thing that it has been doing for the past +20 years. One thing that has changed recently is investor sentiment. Investor sentiment is fickle.

ARCC does lend to software companies. They account for 24% of ARCC's portfolio.

This shouldn't be a surprise because software and services make up a very large portion of the U.S. economy, and lenders are going to lend to the businesses that make up most of the economy. ARCC's focus is on businesses that are in specialized niches with a fairly large moat.

For example, one of its top 10 largest investments is in Symplr, a company that specializes in providing enterprise-level software solutions to healthcare companies. For a healthcare system to change their software is a major and expensive step. The hard part isn't creating the software, it's in creating and maintaining the customer relationships. Even though it's one of the largest holdings in ARCC's portfolio, Symplr accounts for 1.2% of the portfolio.

ARCC lends to over 600 companies. They are highly diversified and there will always be some of their investments that are struggling. That was true in 2005, 2008, 2015, 2020, and today. The business model doesn't rely on every sector and every borrower being in great shape all the time. ARCC lends money, underwrites the collateral, and makes loans.

That's why, after over 20 years and $70 billion of closed investments, ARCC's annual realized net loss rate is insignificant. Source

So when ARCC is trading below book value, we are enthusiastic buyers.

Pick #2: OBDC – Yield 12.6%

Blue Owl Capital Corporation (OBDC) is a BDC that is managed by Blue Owl Capital Inc. (OWL). Over the past six months, we've seen the similarity in names cause quite a bit of volatility for OBDC. OWL has been garnering headlines for its investments in data centers and data center debt. Deals that have nothing to do with OBDC, but every negative headline about how "risky" these investments are seems to have an impact on OBDC's share price.

Then, OWL attempted to merge a non-traded BDC with OBDC. The market threw a tantrum, and the deal was called off as the decline in OBDC's share price made it unpalatable. Many questioned the value of the assets.

Well, OWL just proved the value, selling $1.4 billion across three of its funds: OBDC, OTIC, and OBDC II, the non-traded fund. The loans are being sold at 99.8% of par value to pensions and insurance companies. The batch of loans includes a 13% allocation to "software and services" – the favorite sector for bears to be bashing these days. (OBDC's allocation to the sector was 11%)

In short, OWL just proved that their portfolio is worth well more than the market is currently pricing in.

OBDC reported earnings with adjusted NII of $0.36 and book value at $14.81, generally in line with Q3: Source

Note that this does not reflect the sale of assets discussed above. That sale occurred on February 12th, 2026 and will be reflected in Q1 earnings. That's likely why OBDC is paying a dividend of $0.37 for another quarter, even though that is slightly more than earnings were in Q4.

Management took advantage of the discount to NAV that OBDC has been trading at by buying back $148 million in stock in November/December 2025. They also announced a buyback program to buy up to another $300 million in 2026. These buybacks were at a price averaging 86% of NAV.

This slightly offset the credit-related markdowns of $0.14 in Q4.

The overall credit picture of the portfolio remains stable. Non-accruals came in at 2.3% of cost basis and 1.1% of fair value – slightly better than Q3 at 2.7% and 1.3%, respectively.

Over 90% of OBDC's portfolio remains in their top two credit ratings.

While the public markets have been bearish on OBDC, the private markets haven't been. OBDC had its credit rating bumped up a notch by Moody's in January to Baa2. While their debt was already investment grade, being a notch higher will be a small benefit when they go to refinance their debt. BDCs borrow at fixed rates and lend at floating rates. Being able to refinance the fixed-rate debt at the lowest possible coupon is a long-term benefit for the company that improves earnings.

When we bought OBDC over 5 years ago, we said we believed that OBDC deserved to trade at a premium to NAV. Then it did trade at a premium for a bit. Today, OBDC is a stronger company by every measure. It has better economies of scale, it has higher earnings, it has a higher credit rating, and it has maintained a similarly low credit loss rate. We believe that OBDC should be trading at 100-110% of NAV, which is $14.81-$16.29. That is fair value, and management just proved it in the most straightforward way possible, by selling assets to prove their worth. Our neighbors in the market are giving us an opportunity to buy it at a big discount.

Conclusion

When the market panics, look for the opportunity it is giving you. BDCs have been off to a rough start in 2026. In part, this is due to the reality that their earnings are normalizing. The rapid increase in interest rates created a windfall that we all knew wasn't going to last forever. BDCs borrow at fixed-rates and lend at floating rates, so higher interest rates produced higher than average spreads for them. That is over. We expect that earnings will continue to drift down and return to their historical averages.

They are still paying a high yield, even without the supplements, and there are opportunities to monetize their portfolio either through selling a portion of their positions like OBDC did, or as portfolio companies have IPOs, are acquired, or have other liquidity events. In periods of low interest rates, we tend to see more of that type of activity.

For those of us looking to buy and hold long-term, these BDCs are trading below book value, and they should be trading at book value or at a premium. We're buying.

data.title: Nebius: Sell Before The AI Bubble Bursts
data.description:
As one of the most popular neocloud providers, Nebius (NBIS) was able to greatly benefit from the record capital spending by the hyperscalers on the AI infrastructure last year, which made it possible for the company to quickly scale its business. In the last year, Nebius’s shares have already appreciated at a triple-digit rate and gained additional momentum in the last year and a half after Microsoft (MSFT) announced a deal to rent the company’s GPU infrastructure capacity to execute its AI projects.

However, Nebius also faces significant challenges that could limit its upside in the future. The company has a capital-intensive business model that requires it to spend the available resources to build new data centers to meet the growing demand for its services. More importantly, since the business is unprofitable while the FCF is negative, Nebius needs to constantly access the capital markets to raise additional funds, which has already increased its debt load. If the hyperscalers decide to scale down their AI expenses or the macro environment worsens, there’s a risk that Nebius’s growth rate will decelerate. As such, we can’t recommend buying or holding the company’s shares right now and rate Nebius as a sell.

The Challenges That Nebius Faces Are Significant

Nebius specializes in building large-scale GPU clusters, which it later rents to other companies that are interested in using them to execute their AI projects. With the rise of generative AI, the demand for such services has skyrocketed, and it’s not a surprise that in Q4, Nebius’s revenues increased by an impressive 546.9% Y/Y to $227.7 million.

In the future, Nebius could now expect to generate over $3 billion in revenues annually in the next five years from the Microsoft deal alone. There are also reports that under the deal, Microsoft would get access to over 100,000 GB300 chips that are owned by Nebius and will use them for its AI workloads. A similar deal that’s worth around $3 billion was signed with Meta Platforms (META) a few months ago. While this ensures that Nebius will be able to significantly improve its top-line performance in years to come, there are nevertheless major risks with its business model that make investing in the company an extremely risky endeavor.

First of all, by signing such deals, Nebius will take most of the risks associated with expanding the AI infrastructure. The deal gives Microsoft and Meta financial flexibility as they could pay for access to the computing power when there’s an increase in demand for its AI projects, and also not pay an enormous cost for building and maintaining a data center when the demand has fallen.

At the same time, Nebius risks being left holding outdated GPUs that are quickly depreciating as more powerful chips are introduced. In 2024, following the success of its GPUs from the Hopper series, Nvidia said that it plans to release new AI accelerators each year. Last year, we already saw the ramp-up in production of its GPUs from the Blackwell series, and the company expects to release accelerators from the Rubin series later in 2026. This could suggest that as more powerful chips are introduced, Nebius would be required to constantly spend resources on new GPUs to expand its data center footprint and remain competitive.

We already see this happening since Nebius’s CapEx is expected to be in the range of $16 billion to $20 billion, an increase from $4.07 billion in 2025. The problem is that the company’s business is unprofitable and is expected to lose money in the following years. As such, Nebius is expected to access the capital markets for a while to expand its AI infrastructure. In June, it already raised $1 billion through the issuance of convertible notes. Then, in September, it began to raise an additional $3.75 billion through the issuance of new notes and shares. The problem with this is that it increases the company’s debt load and will likely dilute its existing shareholders. In recent quarters, Nebius’s total debt has already greatly increased. Considering that Nebius is likely to remain unprofitable, while its CapEx increases and the FCF remains negative, the company will likely continue to access the capital markets to scale its business.

This is a big red flag for us, since there’s no guarantee that after all this spending, Nebius will be able to reach profitability and become FCF positive in the foreseeable future to avoid issuing new debt and shares. Some reports from last year indicate that even Oracle (ORCL) struggles with improving the margins of its business that rents Nvidia’s chips and even loses money on rentals in some cases. In addition, with AI bubble fears on the rise, there’s a risk that if the demand for large-scale GPU clusters decreases, then Nebius could be left with lots of depreciating GPUs and a limited ability to turn things around and become profitable. That’s why we find it hard to justify a long position in Nebius, especially considering that the challenges that the company faces are on the rise, while its stock already trades at exuberant multiples.

The Real Value of Nebius

Considering all the issues described above, we decided to create a valuation model and figure out the real value of Nebius in the current environment. In the model, our forecast period includes the next five years, and the perpetual growth rate that we use is 3%, which is close to the historical inflation and GDP growth rate. The cash and debt numbers have been taken from the recent earnings report.

The discount rate that we use is 10.12%. We figured it out by calculating the cost of debt and the cost of equity of Nebius. When calculating the cost of equity, we used the TTM numbers for the interest expense and the total debt numbers from the latest earnings report. For the cost of equity, we used a risk-free rate of 4%, a beta of 2.05, and the market return rate of 7.84%.

When it comes to sales estimates, we expect the company to continue to grow significantly in the years to come. The deal with Microsoft under the maximum extension alone would be able to generate around $3.8 billion annually, while the deal with Meta should yield around $600 million annually in the next five years. The management even stated in the latest earnings call that they’re on track to reach around $7 billion to $9 billion in annualized run-rate revenue, so the aggressive growth rate is expected. We reflected this in the model, and we also assume a continuous double-digit growth rate in all the other years, since in the same call, the management stated that the projects that they plan to implement this year could lay the foundation for the hyper growth in 2027 and beyond.

As for the bottom-line performance, things don’t look as good. The expectations right now are that Nebius will remain unprofitable in the upcoming years. Morgan Stanley expects the AI spending to deliver returns only by 2028. Considering this, we assume in the model that Nebius’s EBIT will become positive only in 2028, while in 2026, it’s going to be only slightly better in comparison to its TTM margin. The tax rate in our model is 15%, which is the rate we mostly use when valuing other companies from the AI field.

As for the depreciation & amortization, it has been relatively high in the past, and we assume that that remains to be the case in the future. This is because the AI accelerators that Nebius purchases depreciate fairly quickly due to the constant release of more powerful chips, which leads to a drop in the value of older chips.

When it comes to the capital expenditures, during the latest conference call, the management said that they expect the spending this year to be in the range of $16 billion to $20 billion. We reflected this in the model. At the same time, we also expect a major increase in spending in the following years. Let’s not forget that Nebius’s management in the same call also said that they expect to achieve 800 megawatts to 1 gigawatts of connected power by around year-end, and achieve over 3 gigawatts of contracted power by the end of 2026. Since it was also noted that the acceleration of the data center build-out will continue in 2027 and beyond, we could expect a major expansion of computing capacity that would require lots of capital spending in the future. That’s why we believe that the major increase in CapEx assumptions in the next few years is more than justified.

When it comes to the assumptions for the change in net working capital, they are not that far from the company’s historical performance.

Under all of those assumptions, our model shows that the enterprise value of Nebius is $18.69 billion, while its equity value is $17.48 billion. That translates to an intrinsic value of $69.08 per share, below the current market price by 30.09% at the time of this writing.

Risks To Our Bearish Thesis

Nebius’s stock could nevertheless appreciate further along with the rest of the market if the macro environment improves. The latest CPI numbers suggest that inflation is not reaccelerating, which makes it possible for the Federal Reserve to continue to cut interest rates in the following quarters as macro risks subside.

In addition, the improving macro environment could prompt hyperscalers to continue to increase their spending on AI infrastructure to another record level, which would be beneficial to neocloud providers like Nebius.

Final Thoughts

While it’s possible that Nebius will continue to trade at the excessive multiples and its share price appreciates further, especially if another major deal is announced, we find it hard to justify a long position right now. Due to the excessive capital spending, the company is unlikely to generate any positive FCF in the next few years, and it will likely be required to once again raise additional capital that will increase its debt load even more. At the same time, at the current market price, Nebius doesn’t offer any decent margin of safety, while the risks that the business faces are significant. That is why we decided to rate Nebius as a sell.

data.title: Iran Escalation: Oil Shock, Gold Surge, Equity Risk
data.description:
I don't know about you, but I feel like I woke up this Saturday morning to a world that has been forever altered, and there is no doubt our investment portfolio will look a lot different come Monday. Over the last two hours, it's safe to say that all of those diplomatic efforts over many years of "strategic patience" have gone up in flames. At the time of my writing this article for Seeking Alpha, on Saturday, the Israeli Air Force ('IAF'), while being supported both logistically and operationally by the U.S., attacked previously unknown strategic and nuclear targets in the center of Iran.

A very important note before we begin: on Seeking Alpha, I will ignore the politics, ethics, and emotions involved with war. This is NOT because I do not feel they are important (they are VERY IMPORTANT). It is simply that this is an economics/finance space, and my purpose here is to make connections to assist you in understanding what occurred and how it will affect the markets when Monday morning's opening bell rings.

Buckle in; we’re going to cover some rough seas together.

From Switzerland to the Bombs

With no small amount of speed, we have moved from where Omani mediators said the parties were "close" to the complete collapse of diplomacy announced by President Trump. This is the worst possible outcome for the markets because, as you all are aware, the markets do not like uncertainty. If the diplomatic process collapses, that leaves nothing but volatility.

Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the markets will be factoring in this next phase when they open on Monday. Thus, the spotlight will most naturally be focused upon the reliability of the global energy infrastructure, which represents a far greater risk than mere sanctions. I will elaborate upon this within the full article.

Compared to what has been done so far, I must admit that today's attack is different and cannot be compared to past skirmishes. Why? Indeed, if you think about it, the Israeli attack on Tehran, particularly given its proximity to sensitive areas of power (Khamenei's office and residence), represents a change because a "red line" that had existed for a long time has been crossed. Up until this point, it was just testing and probing the territory; now we are entering a more serious phase.

When the explicit reference to wanting to "eliminate the nuclear threat once and for all" is made, the message becomes clear enough to identify who the target might be. It would be possible to hit, for example, highly protected underground installations such as Fordow or Natanz. These kinds of operations are necessarily long-term in scope (because they can't be finished off in a few days) and will inevitably enter into a longer-term cycle of responses and counter-responses.

And then there is another very sensitive issue: Trump invited the Iranians to "take back their government" in the last part of his almost eight minutes of speaking about it. At this point, the operation plan goes from being simply military to a clearly political one, which has all the internal instability implications on the country.

Oil and the OPEC+ Trap

As I said before, my first thought goes to the potential victims of this conflict, but my second focus, as an asset manager and analyst, is clearly on the markets and the economic implications. This is also because we're on a platform that discusses financial markets, and it's appropriate to focus on this topic.

So, coming to the crux of the matter: what will happen on Monday in the markets?

The following is my very personal view. I don't trust weekend OTC contracts, which are always very erratic, even if they represent a potential market reaction. That said, my thoughts are as follows.

Many have been suggesting that we shouldn’t be concerned with oil, as OPEC+ has agreed to produce more oil. I feel that this is an overly simplistic way of thinking about the problem. It's not just a matter of how much oil Iran can produce; it's also a matter of how much oil (CO1:COM) Iran can deliver to the marketplace. Iran is not an insignificant player in terms of supplying oil to the world. Iran is the 4th largest oil-producing country within OPEC and supplies approximately 11-12% of all OPEC oil production, which equates to about 3.3 million bbl/day of oil supply. Any disruption to the flow of oil from Iran (whether due to more stringent sanctions or damage to its infrastructure) would immediately shrink the size of the global oil market.

The major issue, however, is a logistics issue. Oil is a physical product that has to be moved, and as you know, a significant amount of the oil passing from the Gulf passes through the Strait of Hormuz, which is actually the world’s only energy funnel.

Approximately 16 million barrels of oil are transported through this strait on a daily basis, and at the narrowest part of the strait, the width is approximately 30 km with very few shipping lanes available in that area. This therefore means that if no complete blockage occurs, it will only take creating additional risk factors (mines, drones, GPS interference, etc.) or increasing the level of military tension in the area to slow the flow of ships and quickly increase both shipping and insurance costs.

I think OPEC+, on its own, can’t solve the issue of price increases because if Saudi Arabia were to pump more oil, there are already alternative pipelines out of the Gulf, but they’re nowhere near as large as those through the Strait of Hormuz. The Strait is so narrow that, while it’s possible to create some alternatives, it will be difficult to get enough oil out of the Gulf to replace the volume going through the Strait each day. As such, if the Strait becomes an operational constraint, the market may face a sudden supply deficit (a deficiency) that no amount of rapid production increases from OPEC+ can quickly make up for; thus, the risk to the price of oil is much greater now than would initially appear.

Gold, Equities, and the King Dollar

The word of the day on Monday will probably be risk-off because during times of conflict or instability, the markets are always seeking shelter from the storm, so to speak.

Dollar

I start by looking at the Dollar (DXY). Although the U.S.A. is actively involved in this scenario, based upon historical precedent, the USD continues to be viewed as the safe-haven currency when the markets are stressed. It is the currency of choice for paying for oil and raw materials and for most other global transactions. Therefore, in the short term, I think we should anticipate a stronger dollar.

Gold

Gold (XAUUSD) should act like it usually does during a period of chaos and provide investors with some protection from the uncertainties that are currently affecting the market. The fact that gold hit an all-time price before the most recent tensions indicates that the markets have already begun to account for this type of tension. If the instability continues, I think you may see additional increases in the price of gold. However, due to the large degree of volatility that is associated with the type of rapid increase in the price of gold, I think it would be prudent to use caution.

Equities

The most key component is the sensitivity of stocks over the short term, i.e., an extremely negative opening price resulting from uncertainty could cause investors to flee to safe havens. However, the true test of a market will ultimately take place not on the first day of trading but on whether subsequent closing prices remain relatively stable. If the S&P 500 index (SPX) continues to fall below levels of support, this could provide a perfect narrative for an orderly reversal of markets following prolonged periods of high valuation.

The most notable difference in today’s environment is that there are three new, highly sensitive factors influencing the markets:

  1. logistical risks associated with Hormuz,
  2. the threat of inflationary pressures brought about by increasing oil prices,
  3. China's position as one of the largest consumers of Iranian crude oil.

It doesn’t necessarily mean a bear market has begun, but it does help to explain how the reaction could be more fearful in nature. In this context, maintaining a significant amount of liquidity remains a rational choice. For me, now is not the time to chase the panic of the opening but to maintain vigilant patience and be ready if volatility were to create real price dislocations. From a financial perspective, cynicism is simply having the discipline to remain focused while all the other players around you are reacting emotionally, allowing you to make decisions based upon your own time frame (i.e., when you want to act).

It's Only Saturday

President Trump described "Operation Epic Fury" as a short military operation. However, the scope of the operation appears to extend beyond that of a surgical attack. It appears as if the mission is a much broader effort, as opposed to a limited engagement to eliminate the Iranian capability for a nuclear weapons program, the missile delivery systems, and the naval capabilities. The objective of this operation is more akin to an attempt to create regime change rather than an operation that is limited in its objectives. As we have seen in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya, we should remember that having air superiority is rarely sufficient to bring down an established government.

Iran may fall into a "survival mode" that could last for months or even years, based upon how long it takes for the current Iranian Government to fall. The most vulnerable and riskiest chokepoint in the global economy would likely be the Strait of Hormuz, because Iran has about 90 million residents and an internally fractured opposition movement. Thus, a long-term situation of turmoil is by no means out of the question.

I think, among the other indicators I have mentioned, there is also the possibility that the global financial markets will experience a strong downturn followed by a quick rebound from that downturn as a result of an elimination of the current political uncertainties. If instead, however, the "survival-and-chaos" scenario prevails with sustained tension surrounding Hormuz, the most relevant macroeconomic risk factors for the global economy will be pressure on oil prices, potential inflationary pressures, and a lower rate of economic growth.

We are only at the end of this weekend, and with all of these types of scenarios, it’s usually better to wait than anticipate. The first real read on Monday will come from the closing numbers. If support breaks down and does so significantly, then liquidity will once again be the most important commodity.

We need to continue to monitor the situation.

data.title: Block Eliminates Bloat To Deliver Ambitious 2028 Target - Wait For Correction
data.description:
I previously covered Block (XYZ) in January 2026, discussing why I had reiterated my Buy rating then, thanks to the promising insights offered by the twice raised FY2025 guidance and the outsized 2028 targets offered during the 2025 Investor Day - as the management projected double-digit growth rates through numerous AI-driven initiatives.

This was significantly aided by the cheap valuations against historical averages/peers, the excellent capital appreciation prospects, and the value creation from the ongoing share repurchases.

In this article, I shall discuss why I am reiterating my Buy rating for the XYZ stock here, with the management notably delivering against their ambitious 2028 growth target as observed in the FQ4 '25 outperformance, the raised FY2026 guidance, and the bottom-line tailwinds from the drastic headcount reduction.

This is significantly aided by their improving business metrics, the stock's still compelling valuations, and the robust use of their growing free cash flow for share repurchases.

XYZ's Commitment To 2028 Growth Targets

Since then, XYZ has been impacted during the ongoing market rotation, with the stock losing -31.3% of its value between the January 2026 highs to the February 2026 lows.

Well, this is before XYZ's outsized one-day gains of +16.8% post-FQ4 '25 earnings call, as the market rejoices at three key developments:

1. Drastic Headcount Reduction

Much of XYZ's tailwinds may be attributed to the management's drastic reduction in their headcounts by -40% along with the raised FY2026 gross profit/operating income guidance, with it signaling their confidence in delivering the accelerated, profitable growth trends through a notably leaner operation.

The headcount reduction builds upon the ongoing reduction to:

  • 10,205 employees in FY2025 (-10.2% YoY),
  • 11,372 employees in FY2024 (-12.4% YoY),

after the multi-year headcount expansion at

  • 12,985 employees in FY2023 (+4.4% YoY),
  • 12,428 employees in FY2022 (+45.8% YoY),
  • 8,521 employees in FY2021 (+55.5% YoY),
  • 5,477 employees in FY2020 (+42.8% YoY), and
  • 3,835 employees in FY2019 (+14.5% YoY).

Based on the ongoing headcount expansion at a 6Y CAGR of +17.7% against their revenue growth at +31.3% over the same time period, it may appear that XYZ's planned headcount reduction may have been overly done indeed, given the growing headcounts' notable contribution to their top-line growth thus far.

This is especially true when comparing XYZ's revenue per employee metric at $2.37M in FY2025 (+11.7% YoY) against its direct fintech peers, including:

  • Neo bank/investment - SoFi Technologies, Inc. (SOFI) at $591K in FY2025 (FY2025 revenues of $3.61B and 6,100 employees),
  • AI lending platform - Upstart (UPST) at $740K in FY2025 (based on FY2025 revenues of $1.04B and 1,405 employees),
  • Neo bank - LendingClub Corporation (LC) at $929K (FY2025 revenues of $998.84M and 1,075 employees),
  • PSP/P2P/BNPL - PayPal Holdings, Inc. (PYPL) at $1.39M (FY2025 revenues of $33.17B and 23,800 employees), and
  • BNPL - Affirm Holdings, Inc. (AFRM) at $1.45M in FY2025 (FY2025 revenues of $3.22B and 2,206 employees),

with it apparent that XYZ's operations remain rather efficient thus far, albeit still a distance away from the supposed market leader in the financial market, StoneX at $23.76M of revenue per employee in early 2025, as reported by Ondeck in November 2025.

On the other hand, given the drastic headcount reduction of -40%, it goes without saying that XYZ is likely to report a notably higher metric at an estimated FY2026 sum of $4.45M per employee (+87.7% YoY), based on the consensus FY2026 revenue estimates of $26.75B (+10.5% YoY) and ~6,000 employees after reduction.

Given that the revenue per employee metric "is an important ratio that roughly measures how much money each employee generates for the company," it goes without saying that the management appears determined to deliver their ambitious 2028 growth targets.

If anything, a similar cadence has been observed in Verizon (VZ), as the new CEO also touts how “cost reductions will be a way of life for us here” and the strategy is expected to fund their “significant investment” towards reclaiming their market leadership in the telecom segment.

These developments are unsurprising indeed, as observed in the market-wide layoffs post-COVID-19 pandemic, significantly aided by the productivity gains during the ongoing AI boom.

2. Raised FY2026 Guidance

It is also important to note that XYZ has already raised their FY2026 guidance, with the gross profit guidance of $12.2B (+18% YoY) and the adj. operating income guidance of $3.2B (+53.8% YoY), notably building upon the FY2025 levels of $10.36B (+17% YoY) and $2.08B (+29.1% YoY), respectively.

Assuming that the fintech is able to sustain these growth rates, it is not overly aggressive to assume that they may also eventually achieve their 2028 growth targets previously offered in the 2025 Investors Day, with the projected:

  • gross profit growth to $15.8B in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +15.1%, and
  • adj operating income growth to $4.6B in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +30.2%,

significantly aided by the likely to be reduced operating expenses from the drastic headcount reduction.

Readers must also note the accretive impact from XYZ's ongoing share repurchases on its adj. EPS growth to $0.65 in FQ4 '25 (+38.2% YoY), thanks to -3.5% of its float already retired over the LTM and the richer adj. net income margins of 6.4% in FQ4 '25 (+1.4 points YoY).

These reasons are also why I am of the opinion that XYZ still looks compelling at my estimated FY2026 P/E non-GAAP valuations of 17.46x, based on the current stock prices of $63.94 and the fintech's FY2026 adj EPS guidance of $3.66 (+54.4% YoY).

This is especially since the management still expects to deliver adjusted EPS of $5.50 in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +32.3%, with the stock still cheap at my estimated 3Y PEG non-GAAP ratio of 0.54x against the 5Y mean of 2.28x.

When comparing against the sector median of 1.01x and its direct fintech peers, including:

  • UPST at 3Y PEG non-GAAP ratio of 0.42x (using the same methodology),
  • AFRM at 0.44x,
  • SOFI at 0.81x,
  • LC at 0.21x, and
  • PYPL at 1.27x,

it is apparent that XYZ has remained compellingly valued as a fintech stock for so long that the management is able to leverage their "intelligence tools" and "significantly smaller team" to successfully execute their 2028 growth target.

This is especially since XYZ still reports a relatively decent balance sheet health at a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 0.06x in FY2025, compared to some of its peers, including AFRM at 1.50x, SOFI at -2.96x (more cash than debt), and PYPL at 0.06x.

These underscore XYZ's ability to incrementally invest in their growth initiatives while directing much of their free cash flow generation of $2.42B (+17.4% YoY) towards future share retirement, with $5.3B still remaining in authorization.

3. Return To Growth

Much of XYZ's ability to deliver the aggressive 2028 targets is linked to their determination to return to growth, through:

  • the expanded merchant network to drive higher user acquisition trends,
  • the expanded lending and banking products to drive higher user engagement and cross-selling trends,

all of which are expected to drive improved monetization trends and higher Gross Payment Volumes [GPV] across both Cash App and Square.

The same has been observed in Cash App's Monthly Transacting Active growth to 59M in FQ4 '25 (+2M YoY) and Primary Banking Actives to 9.3M (+1.7M YoY), along with the growing Inflows Per Transacting Active at $1.41K (+11.9% YoY), as "more customers bring their paychecks into Cash App."

The latter is important indeed, since "these customers have generated nearly 10x the gross profit of peer-to-peer only actives," with it also triggering higher retention trends and spending volumes through the Cash App Card.

Thanks to the tailwinds from the prior Fed rate cuts in late 2025, the fintech has also reported growing "consumer lending origination volume by 50% year-over-year in 2025, while sustaining strong margins and healthy risk loss performance," as similarly reported by other lenders/BNPL players in the recent Q4 '25 earnings season.

This is on top of XYZ Square's growing GPV by +10% YoY, as their international expansion drives accelerated GPV growth by +25% YoY compared to the US at +7% YoY, aided by their expansion into the mid-market seller channels (>$500K in annualized GPV).

Most importantly, despite the growth initiatives and the intensified R&D efforts, the fintech has been able to report a notable expansion in their adjusted operating margins to 20% in FQ4 '25 (+3 points YoY) and to 20% in FY2025 as well (+2 points YoY), with it lending credence to their increasingly efficient operations.

The excellent Return On Investment [ROI] on their growth initiatives may also be why the market has rewarded the XYZ stock with the outsized double-digit rally post-FQ4 '25 earnings call, with the fintech seemingly on track to reverse their previously decelerating growth profile in FY2024/FY2025 while delivering the ambitious 2028 growth targets.

XYZ Remains A Great Buy Upon A Correction

For now, the bulls continue to prove XYZ's new trading floor at the $50s as the euphoric one-day rally pushes the stock to the $63s, thanks to the FQ4 '25 outperformance, the raised FY2026 guidance, and the bottom-line tailwinds from the drastic headcount reduction.

Despite this, I am of the opinion that stock is still a great buy, since there remains an excellent upside potential of +50.1% to my long-term price target of $96, based on the FY2026 P/E non-GAAP valuations of 17.46x and the management's FY2028 adj EPS of $5.50.

If anything, readers must note that XYZ remains cheap against the peer group 1Y P/E mean of ~25x, with the speculative upgrading in the former's valuations nearer to its peers likely to trigger an extremely rich, more than doubling upside potential to my bull-case long-term price target of $137.50.

This conjecture is not overly aggressive as well, since the fintech sector as a whole has been oversold upon the potential emergence of a "K-shaped economy" from the divergence between the "higher-income consumers, who are benefiting from stock-market and home-price gains, continue to spend" and the "lower-income individuals are cutting back as inflation eats into their spending power and the job market tightens."

This is worsened by the recent tariff uncertainties, with further trade disruptions and prolonged macroeconomic normalization being more likely than not - with it already contributing to the fintech sector's steep selloff as observed in the Global X FinTech ETF's (FINX) correction by -31.3% from the 52 week highs.

While it may take some time for the macroeconomic environment and market sentiments to recover, I am of the opinion that XYZ presents a compelling capital appreciation opportunity for those looking to tap into their promising fintech revival through 2028.

Thanks to the outsized one-day stock price action, it is unsurprising that XYZ has seemingly entered overbought territories by the time of writing, as observed in the elevated RSIs and the 20% gap to its established uptrend support line since October 2023.
